huntYears.SEASON_DATE_TEXT: Archery: Aug 23-Sept 19, 2023 & Dec 2-17, 2023/ Any Legal Weapon: Sept 20-24, 2023 & Oct 7-19, 2023 & Nov 11 - Nov 19, 2023 / Muzzleloader: Sept 25-Oct 6, 2023

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The Nebo unit has pretty tough terrain in many locations where you find elk.  Hunters are either faced with straight up or straight down hikes so good physical condition for hunters is a must.  As already noted, the north portion of the Nebo unit is restricted from ATV use so hunters with horses or mules will have the advantage.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: This is a very remote location with some areas with limited access.  Cellular phone coverage is fair over most this hunt unit.  Digital cell phones may show several bars but cannot always connect due to the distance to the cell towers.  Satellite phones do work in the area.  The Biologist suggests handheld radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Depending on the season be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  Thunder storms can cause muddy road and trail conditions.  Most hunters struggle with meat spoiling in the heat especially during the archery season so in anticipation of hot weather plan accordingly.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 100~1450~1700~~~5.5–6.0~6.5~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
The majority of hunters choose to hunt the higher elevation areas during the early rifle hunt. The areas around the Nebo Loop Road being most popular is an excellent place to start. Elk can be seen from a distance by glassing the ridges and canyons from the overlooks on the Loop Road. Since ATV use is not permitted on the north Nebo (that portion of the Nebo that is north of SR 132) there are canyons and trails where you can get out and hike to get away from people. There is plenty of water on the mountain for the elk. However as you hike you can find several unmarked springs. Wildfires have affected the habitat on both the east and west sides of the unit As the burned area reestablishes vegetation it attracts large amounts of elk.

Migration Patterns: You will find elk from one end of the Nebo to the other. The north portion of the Nebo has the greater percentage of the elk population. The south portion of the Nebo unit (that portion that is south of SR 132) has much fewer elk but do not count that out as an opportunity to find a nice bull. The elk will start feeling pressured toward the end of the archery hunt with increased rifle hunters scouting for their upcoming hunt. During the winter months the bulls prefer to stay in the highest elevations. They will locate windswept south slopes and wait out the winter. The cows and calves will migrate to lower elevations. After the calving season you can find large herds of elk at higher elevation in grassy meadows. Once the rut begins the bulls begin to herd up smaller herds of cows and the elk seem to spread out.

Scouting Tips: A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential for scouting elk in this area. Scouting is most effective late-summer to early fall. If you are able to place trail cameras on the remote springs and water holes you will be able to pattern the movements of the bulls. In the hot early fall temperatures expect to see the most animals at prime time (1/2 hour before dawn and an hour before sunset). There are several recovering burned areas that have produced large amounts of grass that is excellent for elk. Elk spend a lot of time in the aspen patches where there is a good understory of grass and forbs. Scouting during the summer is effective for learning the areas where you want to hunt but don't expect to see the same elk on the same ridge during the summer and also in the fall. The elk do tend to move before the rut so focus scouting efforts during the first of September.

Behavior: The elk seem to prefer bedding down in the dark conifer timber during the day. Towards the evening the elk will start to work their way onto the burned faces and points of the ridges. Once the bulls shed their velvet they will start to break up from their winter and summer bachelor herds. They will usually water at least two times a day. It is not unusual for elk to graze through the night. As the hunt progresses and if colder weather moves in, the elk will start to come into the rut. Before they start to herd the cows up the bulls are very susceptible to cow elk calls. As elk get closer to the rut they will become more vocal and will start to round up small herds of cows. The larger bulls will usually try to keep their cows away from contending bulls. It is normal to have one herd bull and other bulls surrounding the cows at a distance. During this hunt it is effective to hunt water holes early on the hunt. Later in the hunt it is more efficient to call and locate the bulls and try to get them to come to cow calls.

huntMaster.SPECIAL_INSTRUCTIONS: Hunters may hunt all limited entry seasons for this unit using the appropriate weapon for the open season
huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Public and Private, Check official map for information.
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: All Wildlife Management Areas are open for this hunt except for the "Private Lands Only Hunt" for antlerless elk.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Many improved and primitive camping opportunities on the unit.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The best access points are off the Nebo Loop Road. Forest Service gates are typically locked beginning in November until late April/early May. However there are many secondary canyon roads that offer access to good hunting. See following link to check seasonal road closures. <a href="https://www.fs.usda.gov/main/uwcnf/maps-pubs" target="_blank">https://www.fs.usda.gov/main/uwcnf/maps-pubs.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: Landowners may or may not allow ATV access.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: Temporary area and trail closures have been put in place by the Forest Service due to fire mitigation on the northern half of the unit. Please click here for more info or call the Spanish Fork Ranger District Office at 801-798-3571. Please Please be mindful of Wilderness Areas and associated regulations.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Juab, Millard, Sanpete, Sevier and Utah counties—Boundary begins at US-6 and I-15 at Spanish Fork; southeast on US-6 to US-89 near Thistle; south on US-89 to US-50 at Salina; northwest on US-50 to I-15 at Scipio; north on I-15 to US-6 at Spanish Fork. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Maps: Delta, Manti, Nephi, Provo, Salina. Boundary questions? Call the Springville office, 801-491-5678.
